#  [](/thread/1254177-no-indicator-trading-system)No Indicator Trading System 

  * 

  * [#1](/thread/1254177-no-indicator-trading-system "Post Permalink")

  * First Post: Edited 6:54pm  Nov 26, 2023 2:18pm | Edited 6:54pm 

  * [![](https://assets.faireconomy.media/nfs/customavatars/thumbs/medium/avatar415963_9.gif) Islandfx911](islandfx911)

  * Joined Jun 2015 | Status: Trader | [1,069 Posts](/search?do=process&provider=Member&searchuser=415963)

Hi All,  
I am posting my no indicator intraday system for you to use as your own.  
I will go through the system from start to finish and when completed I will post live trades and answer any questions you have.  
The system is based on support and resistance of which I can use daily, 4hr, 1hr, 30m and 15m to establish a trade entry.  
I do not get it right everyday so no promises.  
  
All support and resistance is marked up / plotted on a line chart.  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: Line chart SR.png
Size: 15 KB](/attachment/image/4598644/thumbnail?d=1700979316)](/attachment/image/4598644?d=1700979316)   

  
  
Lets look at some different time frames so you get the general idea.  
  
Plot horizontal lines on the most recent peaks and troughs.  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: Daily line chart SR.png
Size: 16 KB](/attachment/image/4598645/thumbnail?d=1700979797)](/attachment/image/4598645?d=1700979797)   

  
  
Now change time frame to 4hr chart.  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: 4hr line chart SR.png
Size: 15 KB](/attachment/image/4598646/thumbnail?d=1700979995)](/attachment/image/4598646?d=1700979995)   

  
  
Adjust the lines so that the daily lines are on the 4hr peaks and trough  
  
The following chart shows the 4hr lines before adjustment to 30m.  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: 4hr lines on 30m TF.png
Size: 29 KB](/attachment/image/4598653/thumbnail?d=1700981704)](/attachment/image/4598653?d=1700981704)   

  
  
Now do the same to the 30m chart so it looks like this.  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: 30m line chart.png
Size: 15 KB](/attachment/image/4598655/thumbnail?d=1700982272)](/attachment/image/4598655?d=1700982272)   

  
  
I will get to 15m charts shortly.  
  
Notes on support and resistance.  
The support and resistance lines will not always line up perfectly, sometimes they will but most of the time not, you just have to work with what you have got, you need to be flexible.  
  
The next chart / charts I want to discuss is my trading screen. I have two charts open all the time, one is line SR and the other is a candlestick chart with recent SR lines added. If you do not have room on your screen for two charts you can set up a line chart and toggle between line and candles.  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: Trading Screen.png
Size: 22 KB](/attachment/image/4598669/thumbnail?d=1700988772)](/attachment/image/4598669?d=1700988772)   

  
  
  
_Support and Resistance Lines_  
SR lines are basically a price where there is a strong change in belief has occurred of the market price / currency value.  
They are reaction / rejection points that we can use to our advantage.  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: Reaction Rejection.png
Size: 25 KB](/attachment/image/4598679/thumbnail?d=1700991736)](/attachment/image/4598679?d=1700991736)   

  
  
SR is visible on all time frames. The following chart shows 4hr SR and 30m chart with 4hr SR plotted  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: SR different TFs.png
Size: 28 KB](/attachment/image/4598680/thumbnail?d=1700992601)](/attachment/image/4598680?d=1700992601)   

  
  
The next chart is the 30m candle chart showing rejection candles  
  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: Rejection candles 30m.png
Size: 14 KB](/attachment/image/4598682/thumbnail?d=1700993065)](/attachment/image/4598682?d=1700993065)   

  
We now have a support zone and rejection candles. Next we want to get into the trade and this you will find interesting.  
The majority of traders enter trades when everything lines up in their favor, I am talking moving averages, MA crossovers, MACD bullish etc.  
If you use this approach you will find it difficult to succeed with any trading system.  
I will explain....  
  
The following chart shows a textbook Close above MA type trade. The only problem is you are giving away way to much of your funds in the stoploss.  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: MA Entry.png
Size: 17 KB](/attachment/image/4598689/thumbnail?d=1700994691)](/attachment/image/4598689?d=1700994691)   

  
  
More to follow....... 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

Have you ever thought with a right set of indicators you can see all the things you want to see on just 1 chart? instead of 4?  
  
Candlestick give you only 4 snapshots high, low, open, and close. And that’s it.  
  
Indicator is based on the range of the price history. It gives a lot more info on how the prices was compare to now.  
  
To me, although I have traded naked for a few years, trading without the indicator is like you try to swim with only 1 arm. Can you swim in the calm water with 1 arm? Yes, you probably will be able to and will do just fine. And yes I had a few impressive runs trading naked. But what about in a raging ocean with countless rogue wave? Are you well prepared for it? I learned my lessons and paid my price solidly depends on just the candles and price level. 

If u luv happiness, start w/ discomfort, make friends w/ pain and failure.

Stop loss and Targets.  
As with all trades I am looking to reduce the stop loss as soon as possible as long as it does not increase the risk of the trade.  
The SL is moved to break even on close of bullish candle shown on chart  
  
In regards to targets I always set a RR of 2.3:1 as a minimum. I started out with a 2:1RR however after three months of trading this way I calculated that 0.3 of the trade was taken up in commission / spread by my broker on each trade. This was eating into both my losing trades and profitable trades ($2300.00 in 3 months)  
  
Note: 2.3:1RR is a good return. I can get 5R and 6R on occasion however it pays not to be greedy.

Hi Eprst,  
I spend 1hr - 1.5hrs a day trading of which all is needed to trade this system. The Asian session starts for me at 8.00am and goes through to 9.30am after that my trading is finished for the session / sometimes the day. After 9.30am the market activity drops right off. The same occurs at Euro session and the US session. There are 1.5hrs of activity at each market open then it goes quiet unless there is Red news out.  
  
In regards to indicators.  
Lets start with a blank 1hr candlestick chart and you put a 21EMA on it, the market starts trading above the MA and your system says buy. You have just created a belief in your mind that the market will go up. You then add another indicator, the MACD and that confirms and reinforces your belief. So you are ready to go, you feel good, your brain is feeling good. You are about to press Buy and you think to yourself I will just check the higher time frames. When you do, the MACD is bullish however, the 21EMA is bearish.  
What happens next? Well, you question your analysis and start to have doubts about going long. Your bullish belief has just been destroyed.  
Even using lets say red and green candles is detrimental to trading because your brain is associating green with up and red with down, same deal, you change time frame and you get mixed signals.  
Indicators are based on price, what are we trading each day? Price. What I have done is eliminate / reduce positive and negative beliefs by removing indicators and colour from my charts.  
If you don't understand how to trade price no amount of indicators will help.  
I have placed three trades this week and netted 6% on a system that I offered to everyone only to have three traders telling me that I need to use indicators to make it work in the long term. Crazy!  
If someone had offer me a system that can produce 6% in two days for 4.5hrs work. I would be onto it as fast as I could.  
Trading is not about banging out trade after trade throughout the day. If you want to be successful all you need is one maybe two trades a day at the right risk / reward and then........ you can enjoy your life. 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

When I place trade I want to be close to the SR zone with a rejection wick visible.

Well well well... combing the support and resistance zones from the line graph is definitely going to be insane for me going forward.  
  
Sometimes I get confused where we are going to be heading to next and I have done for so many years at times... but by following the 4HR support and resistance lines it is going to send me to another level in my trading with my entry method.  
  
I basically trade orderblocks and I use a 0, 25, 50 and 100 fib levels on the last up or down candle before a strong move in the opposite direction as seen below.  
  
I set pending order trades on the 25% zone (Green Line) and then stop loss is the spread after the red (100% of fib levels - Yellow pen marks ive put)... i.e 0.5 pip. Take profit is the next zone (white lines).  
  
Just wait for the pullback and let it enter for you... - Note: its usually best when there is a break of structure or change of character.  
  
As you can see below, it is proving very fruitful if you took all these trades on EURUSD on 15m chart.  
  
Thank you for refreshing my mind by pointing out the line graph to create the zones!!!  
  
Found the entry method from someone on YT - (TFWP) but tweaked it a little.

Hi LT, I use support and resistance extensively with my system for entry and TP. I use CaveManager to place the trade, set initial SL and a TP of 2.3R.  
**Trades don't always make it to TP though.**  
**I will always go to breakeven on the trade when I can.**  
  
So, trade is placed and underway, I then look to see where the key SR levels are to see if I can push out the trade.  
Factors that attribute to pushing the TP out.  
1\. The amount of S/R that I have traded away from.  
2\. Was the trade a from a Daily / 4hr inside bar breakout  
3\. Was the market confined to a tight range prior to trade entry  
4\. High impact news  
  
When I consider pushing the trade out I always keep telling myself "Don't be greedy" It is the best advise I can give you  
You can never think there is more because no one knows, you just have to place your trade as per your plan and attempt to be profitable with what the market gives you.  
You can only control the system rules. Have no expectation of what the market will or will not do. 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

First thing I will do at over the weekend is Line Chart Analysis. If you are not prepared for Monday, you will likely never be prepared for Tues, Wed, Thu or Fri either.  
Lets take a look at some line charts and locate areas to possibly take a trade.  
  
First EA 4hr Chart.  
  
I have plotted support and resistance lines on the peaks and troughs, these represent the candle bodies. I am not saying that the wicks aren't important it's just how my system works.  
You will note two levels of resistance at 6382 and 6394. All that I have done is identify two zones that price might reject and head down.  
I don't know that price will reject these and give me a short entry. I just want to be prepared. After all the market might gap up and I will have to go to plan B.  
If you are prepared you have eliminated doubt.

I like the fact that the second candle takes out the first candle with a wick both at resistance and I take the same trade almost always too  
  
However, it is not just based on the individual candle you posted but both together  
  
The idea being that bears hit the resistance line and then early bears were stopped out and stop-hunted before the main move happened  
  
I feel this is a sign that larger players may be grabbing stops to get the liquidity they need to short with larger size, hence the wick above resistance and the larger move that follows  
  
It is the same theory behind Wyckoff's Spring, Trader Vic's 2B pattern, Shylo's Stophunt Entry, and the recent smart money concepts related to the prior theories  
  
But it'll be interesting to see how it works on its own although I do suspect that on a lower timeframe, there will be a "2B" pattern at play

Risk Reward Ratio.  
After posting the DAX chart I thought it would be a good time to show why I rejection candles.  
Chart 1 shows the way I would enter the trade. Chart two is how I have seen the majority and including myself enter trades using a safe entry.  
**N.B. I am just using DAX as an example as I had the charts open. I am happy to show the same with FX.**  
The safe method is getting on the train as it leaves the station. I am in no way saying that you cannot be successful trading this way because I traded like this for years.  
The issue I had with trading the safe way was the snail pace that my account was going up.  
Why was I risking $100 to make $200 only to get a few losses and go backwards? I did not like the odds.  
Many of you have probably looked at what I have posted in this thread and said he'll be getting stopped out a fair bit entering on rejection candles and you would be right however, trading rejection candles can and will give you high RR (usually a minimum of 5R) The best RR I have had was over 17R but it takes time to spot the runners. Anyway before you place a trade this coming week have a look and see if there is a rejection candle before your entry ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

Hi Jepeto,  
There are many trading systems that are similar to each other however they will never be the same. This can be proved by giving 10 people the exact same system.  
You will find that you will get 10 different sets of results. Trading systems are mechanical, the trader is subjected to emotions during trading (The human element) thus causing varying results. You are welcome here to learn from me and others that post charts and ask questions. This system is not the system of all trading systems it is basic price action with support and resistance along with some supply and demand that is available to all. I have just my twist on it. So please learn with other traders here and we can all profit from knowledge.  
All the best  
Rob

Hi Traders,  
Just a reminder, when you place trades on your own systems check to see if there was a rejection candle before your entry that you could have entered the trade.  
If you can adapt to entering trades this way you will be able to improve the RR on the trade.  
If price has broken resistance it will usually return to pick up more orders at support or a demand zone. The rejection candle will show that I find no reason to wait until price is heading back up. You will be paying retail prices, you want to be paying wholesale prices. 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

Hi Josi,  
You are correct, I enter on the close of the bullish candle that has traded back to the sell zone. The blue candle must have a rejection wick. Many price action traders wait for a downward candle to get in because the brain associates the downward candle as being safe. What would you rather be a safe trader that makes 2R on a trade or learn how to trade like I do and have a TP of 7.5R. How many times can I get stopped out and still be in front compared to the safe trader?  
I treat the buy / sell zones as brick walls I believe it takes effort to break through the brick wall, the market has moved or rejected that price for a reason. If I get stopped out I lose 1%, if I have win I have 7 free trades before I go into negative. Traders have been brainwashed into the 2R principle for so long that they see no other option.  
You are probably thinking 7.5R is not possible but that would be your belief as apposed to mine.  
Thanks for your post.

Hi Pelagiusz,  
If you take another look at the candlestick chart on post 215 you will notice that I plot rectangles from the wick back to the candle body. The wicks are important as they show the amount of rejection. You are also highlighting candles in what I call the dead zone. The Dead zone is a time when the market goes quiet usually before after the open. Another thing, Friday was NFP day and I only trade the Asian Session on NFP day due to the volatility. My trading system is 100% win rate and you will get stopped out. If you would like to learn more about this method of trading I would recommend you open up a 15m and 30m charts in the background of your trading system and just watch for the next two weeks how the market trades during market opens. There is usually 1.5hrs of good trading time. I will do my part to answer your questions and post charts to show you how beneficial It will be in learning to use line charts with no indicators.  
Thank you for asking these questions, I look forward to hearing from you.  
  
I have a question for you. You have two moving averages on your chart, what exactly are they telling you?  
Regards  
Rob

Hi Traders,  
Over this weekend I am going to post my system in detail. If there is anything you want to know just ask the question.  
I used to keep the system to myself as I thought why should I share it with anyone. After becoming unwell the last thing I wanted was money and my attitude changed.  
I have been training a trader in the UK for the last 10 days and found it gratifying. I think the hardest thing about teaching someone is getting them to change their beliefs.  
Beliefs are everything in trading, the can be created, reinforced and destroyed sometimes without you even knowing. Years ago I went to a seminar by Louise Bedford. Louise told us a story about a test she did on her husband. Every morning when her husband came down from upstairs ready to go to work she told him you look great today which put a smile on his face and off he went to work. This happened from Monday to Thursday and Louise told us that he was a different person, happy at work and talking positively. On Friday he came downstairs as usual, a smile on his face and as he walked into the kitchen Louise looked him up and down and said "Your not wearing that are you" Poor old husbands face dropped and he was lost for words. His belief that was created on Monday and reinforced through to Thursday had been destroyed in a matter of seconds.  
  
So, how does this story relate to trading and my systems?  
It has everything to do with trading and my system.  
  
How many of you believe that 2R targets are what you should be getting on winning trades?  
How many of you believe that if the market is trading above a moving average the trend is up?  
How many of you believe that using indicators will make you a better trader?  
  
These are just a few beliefs that you have read or been told and reinforced over time and they will destroy your chances of success.  
Everything about trading has been designed and calculated to keep you from being successful.  
  
More to follow... 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

Hi Traders,  
Okay, down to business.  
  
My system is based on traders beliefs about price at a given time. It also factors in the manipulators that are swinging the market for huge profits each day.  
  
A Tipping point.  
Malcolm Gladwell states  
A **tipping point** is a point in time when a group—or many group members—rapidly and dramatically changes its behavior.  
  
So when enough traders believe or have been told or in trading shown that something is expensive traders will start selling. This creates a mass of beliefs that were created at a set price (Resistance) and reinforced as the market trades lower.  
As you hop onboard when the market goes down your belief is you were right to sell and you feel good about yourself.  
Congratulations you have just been manipulated.

Thanks H for dropping in.  
In regards to my entry being aggressive I will partially agree with you. I think it was Em that said you need balls of steel to enter trades this way.  
I'll give you some more info into why I enter trades this way as it will help others here as well.  
  
I am going to use this line chart again to explain.  
There are two trend changes on this chart and I think you would agree that you would trade them yourself.  
I also know that you are not alone, there is likely millions of traders around the world and some large institutional traders that are forcing the trend change.  
So the trend has changed and we all want to get in on the action.  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: EJ Swings.png
Size: 17 KB](/attachment/image/4634817/thumbnail?d=1705829498)](/attachment/image/4634817?d=1705829498)

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: Safe entry.png
Size: 3 KB](/attachment/image/4634825/thumbnail?d=1705830562)](/attachment/image/4634825?d=1705830562)   

  
My view is that the trend has changed and created a support level and that support level was created by a high volume of traders believing the market is going up. (My belief also)  
When I look at support / resistance I picture a stone wall that would take some getting through.  
I see price trading back to the stone wall and realizing that it's not going to get through a therefore it backs away from it.  
This is the rejection Candle where I get in.  
If I buy something I am not going to pay top dollar for it because I feel safe. I want it as cheap as possible so I can maximize my gains.

Hi Traders,  
This a good time to talk SL and Targets.  
The following is my SL TP for my trades.  

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

[![Click to Enlarge

Name: SL Tables.png
Size: 1 KB](/attachment/image/4634828/thumbnail?d=1705832577)](/attachment/image/4634828?d=1705832577)   

  
  
As you can see the range is 3 to 10. I do not enter trades with a SL greater than 10 ever.  
If I see a trade that requires a SL of 15 for example I will not buy or sell on close of the rejection candle I will put in a limit order with a 10 Pt SL  
These numbers are not random numbers that I have plucked out of the air they are a result of a fair amount of research.  
The TP is always 7.5R 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

Hi Traders,  
I want to discuss The Dead Zone. The dead zone is not a place where they send traders that don't follow their system rules although sounds like a good idea. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)  
The Dead Zone is the time when the market open activity has slowed. The market open activity lasts for approximately 1.5Hrs and then you will get periods of the market drifting, usually stop hunting to take out the weak traders.   
Unless your strategy is to stop hunt and accumulate you should never place trades during the Dead Zone.  
Trading takes a lot of discipline, that is why you must have a plan and stick to it.  
If you miss a trade during the opens, you have missed it so let it go. Do not try to place trades while the market is drifting, it will be the end of your trading career. 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

Just wanted to point out something on the _line char_ t above . The blue arrow at the upper left. Points to a price formation that I like to see. Another trader who uses both line and candlestick charts calls the line pattern a Quasimodo.. In a down move there is a high then a lower high and then a drop.  
When I use a line chart this is one of the patterns I look for... entry on the crossing of the low between the high and the lower high. The pattern shows up in the opposite direction at the lower blue arrow. Much easier (for me) to see on a line chart.

Hi Traders,  
Making your own trading decisions.  
  
I mentioned in an earlier post the story from Louise Bedford about creating a belief, reinforcing that belief and then destroying it in a matter of second.  
Everyone makes mistakes, it is just a flaw that us humans have. Have you ever made your mind up about something and then a little voice inside you says "are you sure"  
That little statement is so destructive it will destroy a solid trading plan.  
Things you must do to remain focused.  
You must be 100% confident in your trading system.  
You have to block out external noise (Opinions of others)  
You must stick to your trading plan.  
  
If you get stopped out and you were following your trading plan this is the best outcome.  
You must realize that you are an individual, there is not another person on this planet that is thinking the same as you, living the same as you or trading the same as you.  
Trade and believe in your system 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

Hi Traders,  
The following chart shows the 4hr trend. I prefer the 4hr time frame over other time frames as it works well with the 15m / 30m time frames.  
The TCL is the Trend Change Line. As the market trades higher I move this line up. When the line is pierced with a strong impulse the first thing I do is wait for a pullback on the 15m / 30m charts. My view will be bearish until the TCL is breached by an impulse move and the I will wait for a pullback on the 15m / 30m charts. I do the occasional counter trend trade if price has moved a far enough distance from the trend line.  
When in down trend always try to enter trades that are double tops and in an uptrend try to enter trades at double bottoms.

dear islandfx911 trader, another good thread!  
  
your approach of using only closing prices reminds me of simone's approach.  
years ago, i brought simoneg and swingtrader together so that they could pour their "buying&selling resistance levels" into an indicator.  
it was created and distributed, but it is too confusing for me and i prefer to draw the closing price resistances manually and with a free eye.  
  
about the deadzone: my deadzone is 3 hours after the london open and lasts until just before the NY open.  
however, i'm usually done for the day 2-3 hours after the london open.  
  
i also found your very tight stops interesting and that you avoid indicators.  
my experience is completely different.  
i have very wide stops if at all and use one or the other indicator successfully.  
but mainly the price movement leads me.  
  
i almost only trade GU and occasionally EU, because it moves very similarly.  
when i have reached my daily target of 20 pips, i stop.  
with my many multiple positions, however, it is quite possible that i then have +200 or more in the statistics;-)  
  
we are all different in our beliefs and as long as we are successful, that's ok.  
  
i wish you many more pips AND of course lots of health & strength in your fight! 

trading is like dancing, don't think and just listen to the music!

Hi Islandfx911,  
  
thanks for the thread! i have a similar approach with S/R on line charts on higher time frames (Daily,Weekly,Monthly)  
And then entering sniper like trades on a lower TF down to 5min.  
  
But what is sometimes not transfered enough in the web etc. is that a good trader has a dozen or a million other kinds of points/"indicators" on his list, which are not described in a simple forum topic.  
Sometimes, even **you** dont know but only your subconsciousness.  
For example trading time, following news, "tick behaviour" etc. make a huge difference in the probability of the outcome.   
  
Keep up the good work and thanks,  
  
Toaster

  * | Joined Aug 2010  | Status: Trader | [286 Posts](/search?do=process&provider=Member&searchuser=153271)

While I have had lots of experience trading, using indicators (moving averages, RSI) in my early years, now trading naked charts (it took a long, difficult period of a complete mind change Inthebox!), I am always blown away by the simplicity (and beauty) of price charts and their narratives. Price has a memory, sell orders get filled at premium, buy orders get filled at discount, and when there are few orders around, the market makers move price to where there are more. Pretty simple, really.  
  
I know it's easy to post a hindsight chart, but as they say, hindsight builds foresight... so here is my take on GU H4 with SR levels.  
  
I understand Island takes trades straight off the line chart, as price reaches those extreme S/R levels... i admit I'm not there yet, I would drop down to lower timeframes to find entries. Personally I'm a fan of all candlestick reversal patterns, including Morning star, Evening star, hammers, inverted hammers, hanging man, M & W Patterns on M15/M5, etc. However I can see the power and simplicity of Island's style.  
  
One question I have for Island is - how do you know when a S/R level going to be a Primary level (strong) or a secondary level (weaker)? Is it based on the number of supports/rejections at that price? Or big round numbers? Or whether price is at premium/discount extremes?  
  
The reason I ask that (and I know it seems a really basic question) is because I struggle with taking trades as price is reaching 'a level.' Maybe I have lingering 'doubts' issues from my days of using indicators... anyway I continue to grow and develop.  
  
Thanks to Island and all who positively contribute here.

I thought someone might find this useful.  
The chart posted combines the line chart which tracks only closing price , with the H and L of price as if it was a candlestick or bar chart.  
Blue Line = closing price. aka a Line Chart  
Black lines = the high and low that a candlestick makes before it closes.  
Your charting package needs to have a certain type of moving average in order to construct this ... but the chart display does not show a moving average.  
The application I have is on MT4 and listed as Moving Average. This version might be special because it allows you to select different parameters as.. high and low ... thus giving the black lines. The setting should be for MA 1 which is the same as the Line Chart... the two charts below are identical.. just posted that way... sorry.

Hi SV,  
I have some info for you regarding which levels are the primary levels and which are the secondary.  
The question stumped me for a while because I have been doing this for so long I do not class the SR as strong or weak, however I can answer your question in the way I see SR.  
I posted this on ITB thread a while back.  
  
_In regards to your question about which A or V to use on a line chart I explain how I see things  
I am only interested in the market opening times where I am looking for a rejection of S/R or S/D.  
For example if the market is heading down prior to open and above support I am wanting to buy therefore if I am correct and the market goes up the line chart will plot a V on the close of that candle after I have entered the trade  
So the obvious A or V for me on a line chart are the ones that are about to occur at market opens. _  
  
The 4hr SR lines can be plotted where there are multiple touches however those touches are not guaranteed to be reversals.  
There was a trader here years ago called Crucialpoint, his view on SR was...  
_SR is like a set of traffic lights, sometimes they are green and sometimes they are red._  
Sometimes SR will hold, sometimes price will smash through it.  
  
So my answer is the primary SR is the is the one that is the prior closest A or V at the market opens whether it is 4hr, 30m or 15m SR  
I am only trade the opens so that is when I am looking for nearby SR.  
  
I have had a look at your charts and you have a good understanding of SR Zones.  
When I draw zones I plot the rectangle from the top / bottom of wick back to the body, this gives me an accurate zone of activity.  
Plot zones ready for pullback, double tops and double bottoms.  
Hope this has answered your question.  
  
Chart 1  
I have labelled the session opens, quite interesting how the markets reacts at the opens.  
  
Chart 2  
This is how I draw my zones.

Hi JT,  
When I trade the Asian Session there are two key times, 3.00 and 4.30. I very rarely place a trade at 3.30, 3.45 or 4.15.  
The next thing to note is that if there is a decent move at 3.00 that will usually be the direction for the day.  
3.00 signal will always be stronger than 4.30 as 3.00 is the start of increased activity where as 4.30 you are approaching the Dead Zone.  
You are always better to start with the trading the trend change if you are new to this as it is easy to spot.

4 points to mention.  
1\. trading is not about precision. it is more like an art.  
a level is not a line drawn by a pen. it is more like a stroke drawn by a brush.  
so a level is a zone. a SL is not on at the candle wick but with some buffer.  
2\. each trader has different amount of risk tolerance.  
each will have their own estimate on much buffer to allow for SL.  
3\. we have different brokers servers resulting in different candles shape and wicks.  
3\. each trader has different trading experiences accumulated through the years.  
  
then we have to ask ourselves what type of trader are we.  
due to different personalities trading like scalper, intraday, swing, position.  
  
in other words, it is only good that a trader after learning a method  
to come up with a system that belongs to him.  
incorporating things that he had previously learnt and build a system that better suit himself.  
and all these come with experiences which involves discipline, hard work and only time can teach you.

Hi T,  
When you trade this system the main rules are Trades are to be entered after market open, Look for an impulse move followed by a pullback (You will often find that the impulse move / pullback has / is happening before market open) This is the pro getting in position for the move. The last rule is when the pullback is going up you short the market on the close of a blue rejection candle and the opposite for going long.  
There is no need for anyone to sit at their computer all day. Trade the Euro session for 1.5hrs, turn computer off. Turn back on 15m before US session and scan for impulse / pullback. I cannot emphasize the importance of this enough, You only place trades in an active market. As you are a short term trader, look at the most recent swings for you analysis.  
Here is the only trade that was valid .  
Hope this helps.  
Regards  
Rob

Hi Traders,  
I traded DAX at open however SL hit for -1R. The SL does not bother me as it should not bother you if you trade this system as I do.  
I am only going to post the winning trades and this is for a very good reason. You need to focus on the winning trades and visualize these trades over and over again.  
You have to train your subconscious into recognizing and placing a trade that has a high chance of being a winner.  
If you fill that database up with winning and losing trades it will cause confusion.  
I would suggest you set up a database of the winning trades on your own computer and when ever you get time free scan through them. This will reinforce your belief.  
I do this at least 30 times a day. Make sure your office or place of trading is quiet and start scrolling ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f642.png?v=15.1)  
Forget the stop outs they are irrelevant.  
Kind Regards  
Rob

If Rob will permit me to answer your question? The candle A you identified is an indecision or hammer candle which is not considered a bullish rejection candle. The candle identified by Rob is the correct rejection candle. A bullish rejection candle is a bullish candle with a rejection wick at resistance, while the opposite is for a bearish rejection candle.   
  
I hope you understand the difference.

Hi M,  
When I place a trade I am following my trading system entry rule, I have no idea how long it will take to hit SL or TP.  
This particular trade was about 12 - 13hrs.  
The confidence in holding a trade comes from believing in your trading system.  
You should be able to place a trade and forget about it.  
You have to remember that I target 7.5R TP with a 1R SL  
You can throw trades at me all day, I love it.  
I will posts my charts prior to tomorrows open with likely entries.  
Why don't all of you put a 0.01 lot trade on with a 15pt SL and 7.5TP. What have got to lose?  
What have you got to gain?  
  
Lets have some fun ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)  
Pairs will be AU, EA, UJ, EJ and GJ.  
I will post any valid setup.  
During the Asian Session the best time to place trades are at 3.00 and 4.30.  
Who cares if we all FK it up. 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

I use pending orders if the wick is large. My max SL is 10Pts so if SL is 18Pts I set a pending (Limit Orders 10Pts from close)  
  
I forgot to mention if a Blue Bullish Rejection Candle retraces to far it becomes a Pin Bar and if you trade it you have defeated the whole point of this system.  
Get stopped out twice at -4 twice on a good rejection bar is acceptable and easy to recover.  
Get stopped out twice at -8 and you are in trouble.  
Never trade a Pin Bar 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

I have plotted what would have been my entry candle and how I would set my SL from your third screenshot, with the assumption that your key levels were what I would have gotten via the weekly > daily > 4H >M30 drills adjusting the lines to better fit the lower time frames as you move your way down.  
  
Personally, I would note candles and SL zones on my chart, post them here and not enter if I didn't feel confident either in myself or the system. But with hindsight you can always revisit your candles and SL at the end of the day to see how it would have turned out. I think of this exercise as attempting a quiz to the best of my abilities and looking at the answer sheet later. Regardless of whether the entry would have moved in your favour, write down your justifications. Double check if your justifications match the concepts shared in earlier posts.  
  
The system is an easy to understand framework to identify entries with good probabilities of success, the risk/reward aspect take cares of the profitability over multiple trades over time. You have to first build your intuition and the confidence both in yourself and the system to take the trades when you see them.  
  
All the best!

Hi Yasmine91,  
thanks for your posts. Already you are understanding Islandfx911's method really well. I am not a teacher or mentor, but may I offer a couple of observations about your limit order? It's easy in hindsight, I know, but they say hindsight builds foresight...  
Anyway, I have drawn the support/resistance area on the 30 minute chart as I see it, using swing points to the left (see my charts attached).   
Also the lower wicks just before the large price drop have the effect of picking up dormant buy limit orders, thus consuming/eroding buyside liquidity that might otherwise prevent the large price drop that happened. Also, price dropped through the BRN (big round number) of 187.000, an important price level. Once through, it can be hard for price to get back above, again because of the way the MMs set up their orders defense levels.   
I wasn't at my charts at this time, so I can't say with any authority, but my order would have been at the last down red arrow.  
I hope this may have helped.  
MantisClaw

Hi Islandfx,  
  
I have been keeping track of your method as there is similarity in price action analysis (highs and lows) with my trading approach. I also used limit orders to catch price retesting and rejecting from levels (Inthebox’s QM method, an old thread)   
  
You mentioned you need to wait for confirmation sometimes (wicks etc), do you also use stop orders and/or market price entries?  
  
The reason of asking is seeing you posted about your health, daily activities, and trade routines. And just a thought that since your entry rules are defined, maybe you can use alerts to help you. Your S/R levels, original SL/ wick levels, or wick itself (if you have clear defined rules around that), are plausible to be used as alerts. You can keep watching the market to see those happening, or an alert to let you know when it is happening. This is my current status to reduce chart time.  
  
take care and stay strong.

Hi Luckytujuh,  
  
Last post on alert unless Rob agrees.  
  
My solution is to code an alert with multiple conditions with alert(). For example,  
  
1\. if you need 6 price level alert on a pair, code a tool which it detects 6 price values. That is 1 tool, 1 alert on TV  
2\. if you want to monitor multiple pairs, code a monitor. It is also just 1 tool, 1 alert on TV  
3\. For Rob’s situation, also can integrate the Price Level and wick size >10pips into one alert tool, also 1 tool 1 alert on TV  
  
The alert () also allows customisation of notification text, such as “price hit 3rd level”, or “XAUUSD meets condition” even with multiple trigger conditions  
  
same for MT4/5

I have a few things to say about this trade, but I will wait till the 90minute period has past and update this post in due time.  
  
**Update on UJ short:**  
**A few pointers:**  
  
1) **Shifting of SL to BE**  
As you can see in the second picture, the price _**came up to hunt for stop losses.**_ This was shared in an earlier post by Rob where there were many times because of shifting SLs to BE, he missed a good trade, this is a very good example. Trade would have been fine if I left my SL as is, I made an error on the app where I place my trade instead of entering $0 for my stop loss, _**I actually unchecked the checkbox for SL (open SL)**_ Please do not commit the same mistake as me. It worked out in the end but it could have easily been a disaster (potential wipe of account with margin call). While the trade worked out in the end and I discovered the open SL in time, I can't say that this is a trade I am proud of in terms of the execution.  
  
2) **Do not rush your trades**.  
I could have also entered the trade on the second candle which is in my opinion a much better entry candle than the first and avoided all that anxiety from the first. Retests can provide you with further confidence that the setup is a good one (think double/ triple tops).  
  
3) **I could have split my entries.**  
Fear of missing out was what drove me to enter at the open thinking what if there was no retest to re-enter? I could have split my position, assume i were to risk 1% for the entry. I could have entered 0.5% to keep my FOMO in check. If the re-test does come, I then enter again with another 0.5%. You can split your entries how you like ~0.33% for 3 entries so on so forth.  
_______________________________________________________  
  
Spotted another trade (AU-short, screenshot 1) that you can consider, wait till the candle closes before you enter. The new candle is a much better rejection candle compared to the first. Personally, I would not expect the trade to be one that you can push out the TP level too much because of the prev day high, today's low and the 4hr support all acting as potential resistance. Additionally, the trade has been ranging in a pretty tight zone prior.  
  
Best to take some partial profits along the way at the levels mentioned above if you do take this trade.  
  
**Update on AU short:**  
I am glad I have two examples on the same session sharing the same reflections, points stated above all could have been applied to the AU short (screenshot 3). I have to admit that I did feel the temptation to shift my SL to BE at the candle marked in green, but then I remembered what happened on the UJ trade... The chart also provided three points of entry, but as shared initially this trade is not one I would think that the TP could be pushed out in the short term, reasons were already provided initially.  
  
I also entered gold on a short but was stopped out (see screenshot 4), not much to say except that it shared similar traits to the AU short so I would have taken partials along the way as well. Currently both my UJ and AU trades are running with some partial profits taken already but man what a sweaty session this is for me.  
  
I tried to post potential entries and pen down my thought processes as the session progressed to journal my thoughts as the candles came along. The intention is not to provide signals for readers to act on, but rather more of a "pseudo real-time" journal of someone trying to apply what was shared in this thread.  
  
Having to manage looking for entries, already entered trades and posting in a timely fashion is currently too taxing for me. Nonetheless, this was a very good learning experience and I hope there is something for readers to take away both good and bad.  
  
I will still post my charts moving forward but I'll probably do a recap after the session or the day instead of the current format.

Hi folks, been a lurker here for a while. Just wanted to drop a big 'thank you' to you Island for the effort you've put in to your system and generosity for sharing it.

Of course, I started this week with some proper over confidence and got a good spanking from the market but yesterday and today I've been back on track, just gotta keep my focus and not think of the results.  
So once again, thanks Island, if I can maintain these results I can't even begin to explain to you what you have given to me and my family.

Hi M,  
There is nothing wrong with taking 2 -3R if you are getting a very high win rate.  
At the end of the day trading is about making money.  
I will often adjust the TP to within support or resistance so my TP is reached.  
Sometimes you have watch a 2R or 3R trade turn into a losing trade before it continues to the 7.5R TP (Painful but necessary) but after you get some 7.5R winners and you look at the $ gain win compared to the SL $ you will learn to ride these trades out the distance.  
Also runners are not 7.5R they are 15, 20,30+ Pts and can go for days. You have to be very trend aware for this.  
I like trading the Asian session because the ADR will be low, this gives me an advantage of having my trade reach 7.5R TP  
Lets use EA as an example, the market has opened and the current ADR is 45Pts (That how much it has moved since open)  
Lets say I get a signal that requires an 8Pt SL which means I need a 60pts TP (7.5R)  
The 10 Day ADR is 108Pts I therefore know I have a chance of getting a 7.5R TP  
If the market has moved 60 or 70 Pts before I get a signal the chances are less of getting 7.5R  
So ADR is important to watch.  
Next using ADR in your favor.  
EA has moved 120Pts up and Euro session is about to open, are you going to buy EA?  
You should be looking for shorts in this situation.  
  
You have to understand the principle of the 7.5R TP and how it came about and then you may have your question answered.  
The calculation of 7.5R is based on the individual pair, daily range, average wick size and few special herbs and ingredients. It took a long time to work out but it works if you get the right entry.  
All I can say is stick with it, become a 7.5R trader and be aware.  
  
Apologies if my answer is a bit fragmented, Hospital drugs still in my system. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f92a.png?v=15.1) I will review in the morning.

A primer on ADR for those who are not familiar with it, yes you can use an indicator to do this for you but I think it is helpful to understand how it works. With that you will also gain an understanding of what tweaking the parameters does.  
  
Daily Range = Daily High - Daily Low  
X Day ADR = Sum of previous X days daily ranges / X  
10 day ADR = Sum of previous 10 days daily ranges / 10  
  
SMA vs EMA:  
  
Simple Moving Average (SMA): Means that if your ADR has a period of ten days, each day contributes an equal weightage (10%) in the ADR calculation  
  
Exponential Moving Average (EMA): Means that if your ADR has a period of ten days, the most recent day (yesterday, t-1) has the highest weightage, and each less recent day(t-2, t-3.... t-10) contributes a decreasing weightage in the ADR calculation.  
For the layman, it means the more recent days matter more, the less recent days matter less.  
  
Which to select (SMA or EMA) for your ADR calculation is personal preference.  
  
Note:  
  
1\. Daily range encompasses all trading sessions (Sydney + Tokyo + London + New York)  
  
2\. Each particular pair has it's own set of distributions as to which sessions contribute more or less of the movement in a day.  
  
3\. 80% of the time, an instrument trades WITHIN it's 20 day ADR, the remaining 20% of the time it trades beyond the ADR  
  
Source for statistic (3): [https://www.litefinance.org/blog/for...verage%20value](https://www.litefinance.org/blog/for-beginners/best-technical-indicators/average-daily-range-adr-technical-indicator/#:~:text=The%20ADR%20indicator%20calculates%20the,periods%2C%20determining%20the%20average%20value)  
  
On next day's open, the +/- of the ADR value will be the supposed range of possible movement.  
  
There is no guarantee that it will always stay within the ADR, trading is probabilistic. But if you happen to see a pair trading beyond the high for example, and see a valid set up from the system for a short or vice versa, you can be sure I will be entering that short every single time.  
  
I have attached some helper screenshots for reference. Timeframe is daily.  
  
ADR is just one additional point of information to include in your charting for determining how much room there is for a pair to move, some additional points I look at that you may consider are:  
  
\- Session Hi /Lo  
\- Areas of potential support/ resistance in LTFs  
  
Honestly, there are trades where I entered on a valid setup, but just entered 7.5R as my TP and pray for the best (not the wisest move), resulting in SLs or BEs where I could have taken a 4,5,6R profit and be happily in profit. I'm learning along the way as well, and have some practical position management tips on post #727 update 2, #744 point 3 on splitting your entries you may consider to avoid leaving too much on the table while ensuring you are taking as much profit as you can.

Support and resistance behave different in trends and ranging markets. they can gets smashed during trends and have strong resilience when market is ranging.  
There should be no being 'worried' when trading. Just find the set up, place the trade and let the market do what it does. We have no control over price, support or resistance. When you accept you are not in control and anything can happen you will become a better trader. 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

When in doubt zoom out (HTF), if still in doubt, sit out.  
  
Sometimes you see zones at M15, but when you move back to M30 the zone isn't there. I would say that you should still base your entries on M30 (recall the D1 > H4 > M30 exercise) and only look at M15 if the SL presented is too big for your risk tolerance. Personally I do not go any lower than M15 for my entries.  
  
Alignment across timeframes is key part to the system shared, here's a helper chart Rob (IslandFX911) shared in an earlier post, always ask yourself where is the 1-2-3 in your charts. Only looking for entries at 3 is enough, notice how 3 is always a trend continuation.

> [Quoting Detto](/thread/post/14755733#post14755733 "View Quoted Post")
> 
> Disliked
> 
> Ok here comes my stupid question, why do we need to mark off monthly weekly daily H4 etc S/R levels when we just waiting for these simple little S/R levels to be broken and retested ? {image}
> 
> Ignored

We welcome stupid questions because everyone learns from it, let's play out your assumption and see if it holds.  
  
Assume you did not mark off your weekly daily H4 etc S/R levels and you fired your charts up and waited for "simple little S/R levels to be broken and retested", now you have entered a trade. We do not know what the markets will do, nobody does.  
  
You have these questions to consider:  
What is my SL if the trade goes against me?  
Where do I TP if the trade goes in my direction?  
If it does go in my direction, how far can I push my trade out? 2R? 3R? 4R? (insert some)R?  
  
If you do not have answers to these questions, where do you look for them?  
  
Not having any clear and defined answers to the above questions before entering a trade is akin to treating the market like a casino, you are effectively gambling and we know what happens to all gamblers in the long run.  
  
Say if you were profitable with this approach, how much of your profit would be eaten away by fees? Will you still be profitable after accounting for the cost of doing business? Even if you are profitable, even a $0.01 over a day, a week, a month, a year is profitable, did this endeavour suggest a good use of your time?  
  
  
This is not a spray and pray, but rather a take aim, account for wind/elevation, hold your breath, before shooting your shot at your target.  
Would you hunt for deers in bad weather/ when it is moving/ in a place where you cannot properly take aim? Or would you find a good spot with a good vantage point, in clear weather, when the deer is drinking water from a lake and is stationary?  
  
Compare the two scenarios and consider how many rounds would you expect to use trying to hunt for one, remember that your ammo is also a cost that you have to factor in when you are hunting.  
  
Doing the higher timeframe drill down to lower timeframes is very necessary as it gives you a clear idea on what your answers will be for the questions stated above. Prep work exists for a reason, and initially it seems like a lot of work but trust me it gets easier over time if you do it often and do it with focus.  
  
This thread "teaches you how to be a successful hunter (in the markets), from when to pull the trigger (entries) and where are the best spots to find deer (price level)", and is written by one who spent large amounts of time figuring out what works and what doesn't. If it is included as part of the teachings then it is there for a reason.  
  
"Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time." -Rob  
  
Skip steps at your own risk.

Hi Detto,  
  
just my 2 cents, from reading posts from this thread and my way of trading. I only analyse charts at entry timeframe.  
  
The strategy starts with marking S/R levels from higher time frame to entry timeframe, adding and adjusting levels when scaling down.   
  
so if picking levels only at entry timeframe, just go with the end points of swings (HH /LL), and strong S/R. Most likely these levels are seen on other timeframes.

"doesn’t always show as a 123 pattern" I believe this is a misconception. The 1-2-3 is essentially what the system is trying to trade (see post #51)  
  
All the other factors helps to push the probability of success in our favour:

  1. "support and now treating it as resistance" and vice versa is we use to identify the 1-2-3.
  2. "within correct times" ensures that our entry at 3 is supported with good volume
  3. "price has been going up prior to market open", this is not gospel, but it is common knowledge that in order for big orders to fill (from institutions), there needs to be enough liquidity (volume), hence there will be instances when they have to push prices up in order to have that liquidity to push it down or the other way around. We look at what is happening prior to session open because most of the volume is coming in during the first ~90 mins of session's open.
  4. "rejection candle to sell" and vice versa is confirmation that the zone we are looking to enter at 3 is valid, before we enter a trade

I hope this clarifies ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

You can also view both the moves as one giant 1-2-3 (third screenshot)

Hi lolxhaha,  
  
Wish you all the best. In my 4th month trading I came across InTheBox's price actions strategy (Over and Under / QM), he is a very good price action trader and have similarity with this method of Island's. I used this price action with limit orders (very close to how Island uses limit orders), but I then moved on to add 1 confirmation signal to better convert into an alert based trading system (TMS).  
  
You are in a good start so I believe you can have a good account growth soon. Success starts from not failing. I think you are in very good start line compared with many traders who suffer from years of losing money and learn the hard way.  
  
Now you have a good strategy, 2 cents on working on account growth.  
  
1\. **Risk-based management** \- My personality is towards capital protection. I developed ways on how to control risk and risk of ruin. The first step is to prevent your account size go below deposit (i.e. first goal is not to lose a cent to the market). Focus on your risk first, then to step 2  
  
2\. **Achieving a consistent ROI** \- Your trading will accumulate into meaningful statistics. Instead of a fixed $ or % growth, I would suggest going with %gain/%risk, like Profit Factor calculation. This information is independent of your account size/deposit, etc, and is truly assessing your trading performance. This is useful in finding out strategy based information such as alpha decay and consistency.  
  
3\. **Earning a % / $ and scaling up** \- The ROI converts to actual profit $ based on your risk and account size. Once you have a consistent performance and you decided the risk management model, then scaling up account growth will simply based on risk per trade and account size.  
  
I started with $2000, then $4000, then $25000 as deposit. Now is prop firm + personal account of $14k with capital from previous profit. This is a good evidence to myself that it can be done within 3 years. I believe you can do that or even better.  
  
Good work.

Good morning/afternoon/evening traders, relatively quiet start of the week for me.  
  
Since we are well into the dead zone for the Asian session, just thought I'd provide an example of a trade entry which I have spotted where there isn't a clear rejection as shown in Rob's earlier post quoted above.  
  
If you looked at Gold during the Tokyo session hours, you would have spotted one such entry on the M15. Of course, trade has to respect all system rules.  
If you didn't take the entry on the M15, no worries because on the M30 there was a valid rejection candle as well, which was the one I took.  
  
Regardless of which entry you took M15 or M30, either entries trades with would netted you a ~4R TP.  
  
Don't feel bad if you didn't take the M15 entry, you would do very well if you can plan and execute the system with rejection candles alone as that should take up the majority of your trades.  
  
I just thought it would be good to have more examples covering the quoted post.  
  
I'll take a breather and come back during the London Session later.

Hi fxpider,  
  
Thank you for taking the time to post your questions. I am not too sure on the specifics of what you are asking, but let me try to address those which I can:  
  
**_"thought process to incorporate the HTF S/R while taking the trade or forming a directional bias?"_**  
I have attached several screenshots with annotations, please go through them and post further questions if you have any.  
1st: Daily Line, 2nd: H4 Candle, 3rd: H4 Line, 4th M30 candle  
  
**Update: One thing I forgot to include, always ask yourself where is the 1-2-3 across the timeframes**  
  
**_"which takes precedence between HTF and LTF?"_**  
Always prioritise HTF > LTF. Entries are spotted on lower timeframes (M30/M15) but biases tend to come from HTFs, they are there to inform you of where you may possibly want to look for/ exit trades / take partials. If you form biases over LTF you run the risk of entering trades based on noise rather than signal.  
  
_**"The LTF bullish move before the market OPEN and the approaching HTF resistance. (a possible move to the POI to fill the PRO's orders) And, the setup with the rejection candle was at the HTF resistance. ( We cannot buy into the resistance) While that 4-hour candle was still forming. (could have been a rejection candle @close)"**_  
This portion of your question I do not fully understand, perhaps you can annotate on your chart given which area is referring to which part of the question, and I'll take them in a follow up post.

I have marked out zones which i would have drawn if your chart was what I saw during each of the respective sessions.  
  
A few pointers to note:

  1. **Zones are drawn from the wicks to the candle body (see post #27/ post #83 as examples for both S/R zones)**
  2. **If you have difficulties identifying the peaks/troughs/spikes, they usually become clearer when you switch the chart type from candlesticks to line.**

As to your doubts on trade entries, nothing wrong with the first, it was the one Rob posted but I struggle for the following:  
  
(1) see how your zone in cyan was drawn (which candles did you pick, specifically)  
(2) given how "squished" your chart was, I wasn't able to identify the correct candles/wicks that would have led to your first entry  
  
The first trade looks similar to the one from post #77 of this thread, if you need an example (note the similarities in how the zone was identified in the M5 candlestick chart, not the candles)  
  
**For your line chart, may I suggest you drag along the price line (y-axis of your charts) to make the peaks/troughs/spikes more apparent?**  
  
Regarding your second entry based on the resistance zone I had drawn and used for the first entry, I wouldn't take it because of the following reason:

  1. Candle body have invalidated the zone, with it going over and closing above zone drawn for the first entry

  
I believe you took the trade because of the cyan zone you drew, which incidentally was also the zone you used to take your first trade. This brings me back to the pointers I stated above for the first entry.  
  
The mistake for the second entry was not due to the pinbar candle (in red, that is a bearish candle, not a bullish rejection candle), but because of the zones (middle cyan) being drawn incorrectly. Additionally, we would not take the trade if the candle body closed within the zone, it has to be below for a resistance zone (as per system rules).  
  
As you can see from the first entry, there isn't obvious reverse direction movement prior to each of the sessions open candle (no obvious gradual push of prices up prior to session open in order to sell it), instead it is a continuation of direction that occurred prior to the entry. Echo-ing what Rob has mentioned, take the trade based off the signals the market provide in accordance to the rules. Not always will you get a strong pullback into the previous S/R levels right before the session open, and sometimes you even get the move happening before it, the sessions just provides additional volume to push it up/down.  
  
Good attempt for trying your hand at applying the system shared with trades of your own![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44f.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44f.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44f.png?v=15.1), keep trying with focus and discipline and you will soon reap the rewards ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

Zone (yellow box) is largely correct, however do take note that it is **drawn from wicks to candle body (if the zone was drawn from HTFs, do adjust them on LTF or draw a secondary zone)**  
  
Entry candle is a bullish rejection candle (setup valid), but I would not enter into the trade for the following reasons:  
  
1) While the candle is not a pin bar, the wick has quite a distance from the zone (SL too big, poor RR)  
2) The wick of the bullish rejection candle did not go beyond the upper boundary of the zone (yellow box).  
3) If we treat the red news (FOMC) like a market session, the opening candle was a very very bullish one with strong volume. Note that the opening candle usually marks the direction of the session, as such I would prefer looking for a bullish continuation, rather than a bearish continuation.  
4) The zone you marked as potential resistance has not been tested (no double/triple tops)  
  
If I was looking for a bearish continuation I will wait for more candles to show until I get one that is:  
1) Closer to the potential resistance zone  
2) The wick of the bullish rejection candle goes beyond the upper boundary of the zone (yellow box).  
  
Of course, the following has to also adhere to system rules:  
**1) entering only on candle close from respective timeframes**  
**2) trade taken during open to 90m of open**  
3) All other rules as already mentioned before

Day 2 Update; Similar story to yesterday; BE on #1, SL on #2. missed the Asian session as the injury couldn't get me out of bed.  
  
Builds from the previous approach;

  1. Flipped back to the line to see areas of peaks and troughs
  2. Sized zones from candle wicks

  
Missed the aggressive push-through from the start of the London session: Would this approach require the need for a retest or would such a bullish candle through SR trigger entry? I have found the two types of candles from earlier in the thread (image below) - are they the only two for beginners?   
  
Sized the new Zone from the London session, but all action around it happened outside of the 90-minute window. I think I would have got SL if I did take it as entry after the big red candle was retraced instantly.   
During US the session, took a short after the third candle, it went long enough to move SL to BE which then triggered. I think on reflection the candle had a long wick at the bottom so maybe not the right candle to action on as that shows there was some retractment.  
Took the second trade on the final candle as the preceding blue had a wick pulling from the zone. That trade then hit SL.  
  
Two questions for support;  
1) are my zones a better reflection of what is expected?  
2) Was I wrong to select those two candles for entry?

As more questions came in recently regarding the system shared in this thread by Rob, I have a few things to say.  
  
**_Trade-related questions of similar nature like this in future will not be answered:_**  
Throwing un-organized/random charts as a post and asking "Is this correct", "Should I take this trade".  
  
_**Ladies/ gents, your learning is ultimately in your own hands (Most relevant information are already posted earlier or by Rob)**_  
Yes, it is tedious to go through 1000+ posts and read every single one, or filtering through to look for the answer to your question. But inflating the post count in this thread with badly constructed questions will only serve to make the problem worse because there are now more posts to scroll / filter through, for you and other readers in future.  
  
**Before you ask any questions, take the appropriate screenshots.**  
At least your line chart + your candlestick chart if regarding a trade. Try to follow the format which was taught to you, it will be easier for the seniors to understand your questions and for fellow learners of the system.  
  
Can I give you the answer directly? Yes, but what is the point of spoon feeding you?  
You will either take or not take that trade and come back with the same question again next day/week/month.  
**Providing signals is not the point of this thread.**  
  
"Why can't you just tell me the answer?" By doing so, here is what will happen:  
**1) You will never gain the self-confidence of being able to spot and enter trades _by yourself._**  
**2) You will not own your mistakes, since the final decision to trade or not is made by someone else.**  
**3) What will happen to you when person X is no longer here/ not available to respond/answer you with a yes or no?**  
  
Trading is a very personal journey, everyone are at different stages along the journey.  
Everyone is trying to reach similar destinations but our paths will almost always be different.  
We are trying to give you a compass/map to navigate yourself, not a taxi ride.  
  
In addition to posting your charts with your questions, please spend some time to ponder over these few pointers and include them together with your question:  
  
What are your reasons for entering this trade?  
Specifically, what are your analyses (in terms of timeframes/ zones/ candles) that led you to believe/ told you that this is a trade to take?  
  
This will help those replying to your question(s) be able more easily identify these:  
1) What did you do correctly  
2) What did you not do correctly  
3) Point you to relevant information to other posts to help you clarify (2).  
  
**Do remember to take your own notes of the system rules/examples/ the like. Even something as simple as noting which post # relates to what will save you time from having to scroll/filter/search through the entire thread to find what you need, you will re-visit some of the information definitely in future. Think of it as placing bookmarks for important chapters in a book that is ever growing.**  
  
If you are sharing trades your took based on Rob's system or any other systems allowed, feel free to post away.  
If you are a new trader trying to practice / learn the system, do ensure you have understood the information shared. Ask away if you have any questions relating to the system, no charts are needed.  
  
We are all cheering for your progress/success. Help us help you.

Continue working on spotting trades and if you have the bandwidth, try to increase the pairs you are scanning.  
  
I suggest starting with 3, pick them based on the predominant session you tend to trade. If you are only looking at one, there is a higher likelihood to force trades (taking trades where there are none) during times where there are nothing much going on in terms of trade entries, because you are focused only looking at one pair.  
  
As Rob mentioned earlier, if it helps you, you can pepper your charts with notes the gist of what the chart is telling you. It could be something like:  
"1-2 formed, look for 3 at next session", etc.  
  
As always, if in doubt zoom out, if still in doubt sit out

> [Quoting Fantomslayer](/thread/post/14770085#post14770085 "View Quoted Post")
> 
> Disliked
> 
> Hey Rob, Is trading during the first 1.5 hours of a session mandatory? I am missing out on a lot of trade opportunities, which is why I am asking this question.
> 
> Ignored

Most should follow the rules as much as possible. That being said, there are examples where the rules are bent. You may refer to post #826, where rob took a trade before market open.  
  
Coincidentally, I took a gold short today after the 90 minute mark during the london session. This was my first time breaking the rules, so I feel rule-breaks / bends should be few and far in between your regular trades. Additionally, rule breaks should still follow all system rules in terms of your HTF -> LTF analysis and entry criteria.  
  
P.S: Before you look at breaking rules, may I suggest you increase the number of pairs you are scanning for trades. Ideally you should have about 6 - 9 pairs to look at during your most active session(s). It should be easier for you to identify setups on a variety of pairs rather than looking at a few and having to overfit the system with rule breaks. It should be treated as a last resort, and should only be experimented with only when you have good mastery of the system.  
  
To prevent forming of bad habits (i.e tendency to break rules increases, once you have broken rules a few times. -> If I can break this rule, I can break other rules, etc). Again do so at your own risk.

I don't have specific rules on how to set stop losses, aside from the >10 pips use limits as shared by Rob, and minimally targets should be 2.3R (to account for fees/ commissions from your broker). There are quite a number of factors to consider, some use the zone boundaries as a guide some use the wicks as a guide and depending on the setup (wicks exceeding zone or not) you may have to roll with the punches.  
  
SLs differ from trader to trader, but you should keep in mind to have a reasonable risk reward ratio. I think at least having 2.3R is a good starting point. If many of your trades are 1:2R or less from one zone to another based on the system rules it could be a sign that your SLs might be a little too wide.

The upcoming red news at 9:30 (local time) also made me uncertain as to which direction the market would go. I placed a buy limit at the upper bound of the zone with a smaller SL.

**using multi time frames trading.**  
  
q2. i prefer to see a clean chart every start of day.  
i use d1 and h4 in your example as my**directional bias**  
from the time you go to your computer and open a chart, the focus is on **current market price**.  
draw 2 lines closest to current market price, one support and one resistant in each time frame.  
so now you have 4 lines.  
where is price now relative to the above 4 lines that you had drawn?  
clean clear chart no multi lines to clutter my view.  
  
q1. using your m30 as entry chart.  
again the focus is on **current market price**.  
again where is price now relative to the 4 lines that you had drawn?  
above? below? in the middle?  
the only job now is to **patiently wait for the entry set up**.  
whether it is a line or a box according to the eyes of the individual that bring comfort.

Good sharing, and I think it will be even better if accompanied by the understanding that price movements are limited by time. For example, when you see several candlesticks arranged to form a unidirectional movement in the H4 time frame, it will have the strength to form one candle in the D1 time frame, but this still cannot guarantee that one candle in the D1 time frame will be confirmed as a bull candle or bear candle while today's market has not closed. To get an easier understanding, you only need to switch to a higher time frame to compare the achievement of the high price, low price and closing price between a candle that is currently moving and a candle that has previously formed.

For the EU short, yes you are right that on the M30 there would have been no entry. Mine was found on the M15. As for the question of how far back on the LTF do we go back when gauging zones, no strict rules sometimes price will respect a very recent zone created hours before, sometimes price will respect a zone 3 days ago. If lets say the price is exploring a new area (i.e when you look left of the candle its very "empty", then you should keep looking back until you find something unless its at all time highs / lows. When the price is not exploring a new area, then prioritise your zone to have multiple touches, or zones has been confirmed to be s/r flips. The line chart will be your best friend for this.

Hi Machiyara, although this question of skipping the HTF -> LTF drill down has been asked before and answered by ITB, let me take this question again for clarity.  
  
The short answer is **yes, because context is key.**  
  
The long answer:  
(1) HTF lines, for example H4 tells you where price might possibly head to within a four hour window, same goes for daily timeframe. This is the reason why we want at least one S/R above and one below for each timeframe (2 for H4 + 2 for D1) near the current market price as those are the key levels most relevant to the price at that point in time.  
  
(2) We generate our directional bias from the HTF (daily) and MTF (middle timeframe charts, in this case H4), they give you a sense of whether you want to be looking for longs or shorts with your M30 /M15 entries. This alignment is important as we want to lean on the side with higher probability. Will it happen every time? **No, there will be times when all the stars align and the trade still goes against you. The sooner you can accept that and move on the better.** What we are trying to do is to have as good of a chance as we can get with every entry.  
  
Let me give you an example, if let's say you did not do the HTF -> LTF drill down and supposedly it was a bear (d1) -> bear (h4). Yet on the entry timeframes (m30/m15), you spot a 1-2-3 but it is a bullish one. Would you take the trade? Suppose you do, nobody knows whether it will work/ not work out for you but you have to keep in mind that **_one H4 candle is made up of 8 M30 candles. Similarly one D1 candle is made up of 6 H4 candles, and thus 48 M30 candles._ **What is the implication of this point? The trade may work out for you in the very short term and come back to bite you in the medium/ long term because you are swimming against the currents. While the system uses timeframes that would be considered short term day-trading, please do not misunderstand it as a scalping one.  
  
(3) HTF/ MTF gives us an idea of where you can place your TP targets. If you plotted every zone in the M30, you would (1) have a lot of zones, (2) have a high chance that zones are very close to each other. Say you entered a trade on the M30 and now it is the dead zone after your entry (> 90 minutes into the session). Are you going to sit in front of your computer and watch if the price is pushing past or rejecting every M30 zone in the way?  
  
The whole point is to trade and be able to live your life, not have your life revolve around trading.  
  
You may refer to these posts earlier that touched on your question:  
**Similar question from @Detto:**  
#839 [https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/...3#post14755733](https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/post/14755733#post14755733)  
**Responses from @ITB:**  
#840 [https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/...6#post14755756](https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/post/14755756#post14755756)  
#841 cont. [https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/...0#post14755810](https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/post/14755810#post14755810)

#846 cont. [https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/...7#post14755987](https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/post/14755987#post14755987)

#844 [https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/...8#post14755878](https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/post/14755878#post14755878)  
  
**Side note** : The thread will continue to expand, I urge all readers to "bookmark" information you deem important. There will be times where you need to either re-visit some of the concepts taught or when someone asks a question that you might also have.  
Skimming the entire thread from start to finish, you will not be able to retain most of the content. Go through 10-20 posts at a time, digest it, practice it and create your own notes/bookmarks/chapters, how you do it is up to you. It will be tedious and may take some time now, but will pay off immensely in the future, remember that **your learning is in your own hands**.
