Both the EURUSD and GBPUSD are correlated, notice how the line charts are very similar. Take note of the key levels on your MTF and HTF.  
  
I like your trade in the second chart, it was a good trade. I suppose your TP was somewhere around the key level you marked out in orange. If you took partials around the key area you should be in a good position (if you set your SLs properly, it should have easily netted you +3R). Perhaps you can look into how you placed your SL. Shifting BE to +2R is alright but before you do that do take some partials first.  
  
For the AUDUSD, the NY session opened with the price sandwiched between the ADR on top and the key level below. If you look the market open till 90minutes into the session, the NY session was trying to bounce off the London lows to go up but was quickly rejected at the ADR. I would be wary of entering trades where the market is not sure of which direction to go.  
  
Do include your ticker names, I could tell the last was AUDUSD but between your first two charts i couldn't really tell which was GU and which was EU since they are very similar

Spotted a gold continuation trade and took it.  
If you look at the 4H chart the zone is there, but notice we did not have a bearish rejection candle, but note that **H4 candles are made of multiple LTF candles**. Using the H4 zone overlaid onto the H1 chart the bearish candle shows itself.  
  
If you were scanning for entries using M30/M15 zones it would have failed the rules. I thought it is a good reminder that H1 charts are also usable for entries.  
  
The LTFs are there for you to enter at the **right place** without a humongous SL.  
  
Thought I shared a H1 example as well as we don't have many of them in the thread. Last image is a screenshot from post 1

Some of the more experienced traders probably know this but I thought it would be helpful to newer traders.  
  
I hypothesised that **news(red) could be treated like separate sessions** by looking at volume of past news. Here are some screenshots on today's trade that support my hypothesis.  
  
Although I'm not too sure how long does the "news effect" last, for simplicity sake you may treat them as a session (90mins since news).  
  
For those on tradingview, you can hover over the candles and if your settings are not changed you should be able to see them in the top left side of your charts on the tickers with the OHLC information.  
  
For MT4/5 users, charts by default come with a volume indicator as well. Note that **indicators aren't allowed** so you will not see them in future charts.  
  
Just keep a mental note whenever you see news upcoming.  
21:00/ 9pm is my local time that corresponds with the NY open for those confused.

I would sit out or look at other pairs for better opportunities, reasoning annotated on my provided screenshot. A very short or no wick when the candle closes suggests strong price movement in the direction (bull or bear). The subsequent candle could carry that same momentum in that direction. The wick is proof that at one point in that timeframe the price went there but ultimately closed below/ above that price, hence the "rejection".  
  
A candle that does not have a noticeable wick or none is just "bullish / bearish ~~rejection~~ " if you catch my point. "Thrust" candles are just a term Rob gave to these candles with little to no wicks, because of a lack of "rejection". You can refer to post #87, #93, #94 where a similar question regarding candle selection was answered by Rob on post #94.

Well done! Good trade but I just wanted to clear your misconception of the 1-2-3, it is correct in the sense that there is a 1-2-3 present just that the numbering is slightly incorrect.  
  
(1) refers to an impulse, which in your chart would have been the bullish move origin all the way till the recent swing high  
  
(2) is the pullback from the recent swing high to where your entry candle is  
  
(3) is the supposed continuation of the (1) impulse move which begins with the subsequent candle when your entry candle closed  
  
so how does the correct 1-2-3 look like?  
  
in your chart you just need to replace where it was stated 2 with 1 and 3 with 2. All other numbers can be removed 3 is at where your entry candle would be.  
  
This does not take away anything from a good trade which you entered, I just wanted to clear up the misconception in case others who saw your chart may become confused or pick up on the misconception![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d-1f3fb.png?v=15.1)

Spotted a re-entry candle on the M15 after initial long got stopped. Price hit 4R which I exited 80% of my position to cover my first entry and then some while leaving the rest to run at BE, target is the initial target of the first entry.  
  
Update: Runner hit TP target @ 12R.  
  
**There is a very fine line between a valid re-entry vs revenge trading.**  
If you are looking for re-entries after your first trade has been stop hunted, do note the following:  
  
\- re-entries should still follow the system rules  
\- wait for clear indication that your first entry (direction is going in your favour, PA will be your confirmation for this)  
  
If you are not sure of the market direction, it is better to stay out and let the market play out. _**Being stopped out and then having the trade go in your direction is a good loss in my opinion. Because this is a problem which you can fix that is within your control.**_  
  
If you have find yourself often re-entering trades, it might be a sign that your SLs have been consistently too tight/ shifting SLs too early. **You will only be able to notice if you have been journaling your trades.**  
  
Treat the root cause (fix your SL setting) and not the symptoms with band-aids (often re-entering).

Here's my rookie mistake I made today.  
  
Didn't see any trades I'd like, but I noticed this one. I entered it later than I should've, therefore, my maximum 10-pip SL wasn't below the candle.   
  
I have a line in my plan "if for some reason you're late for a trade or a wick is too large, you can place an order with an appropriate SL." — this would have prevented this mistake and I would be in BE already.  
  
I'm not beating myself for it, but it's a great example of what intrusive thoughts can do.

don't know whether you are a new trader.  
  
but here's a list of mistakes they often made.  
1\. big lot sizes resulting in 10% loss 10% win.  
2\. add on to losses with big lots (revenge trading?)  
3\. breaking rules now and then, which becomes a bad habit instead of building up consistency.  
4\. not waiting for market open.  
5\. not doing higher time frame analysis.  
6\. trading without stop loss.

Sometimes a Trade just doesnt work out and you need to accept that losses are part of the game.  
  
You cant make money without losing some.  
It's a business expense.  
  
Instead of asking yourself why you got stopped out, ask yourself whether you followed your Trading Plan or not.  
  
If you did, good job. Next Trade will be a win (or maybe not)  
  
If you didnt, then you should ask yourself why you didnt.  
  
You can always make up reasons in hindsight why something didnt work, but the Market just has randomness to it (a lot).  
  
We can control when to toss the coin, but we cant control the outcome.  
  
Emmanuel seems to be one of those that give great advice when everything has happened already. 

The subconscious mind is in control, not the conscious mind.

Hi, long time no see.  
  
Found out that even with 2 trades per session I was overtrading and getting into non-ideal scenarios. I finally learned to be OK without making a single trade in a day if I don't see one. I work full-time from home and check charts every day, I see strong breakouts that I would have traded earlier to avoid missing out, but the setup is either not valid in HTF or a complete 1-2-3 doesn't appear.  
  
Today is thursday, and this is only my 2nd trade this week (the first one was BE). This one is also at BE already, so it's better to sit on my hands than collecting stop losses day after day. I hope to be able to find better trades by taking fewer of them.  
  
(The entry was a bit late though)  
  
BTW, I recommend turning the profit tab off. I've done it a few weeks ago, and not seeing your profit/loss ranging is lighter on your head.

AJ. my thought process before trade entry.  
always start your analysis from w1, what it tells you.  
a lot of intra day traders ignore the weekly or the monthly.  
the weekly aligns with the monthly up trend. this week may be reaching to last week high.  
move down one time frame at a time.  
the daily range showed a bounce from below 50 fib to above.  
the h4 shows potential long set up.  
now waiting for frankfurt and london open with my entry time frame for long set up. if none then no trade.  
keeping in mind this week target is last week high, as intra day trader expectation, probably the target could be previous day or session high.

it is a Money Management Strategy using the same setup candle and different Risk-Reward.  
The Risk is always the same but different Reward.  
The higher the Reward the lower the Win Rate.  
  
You can trade manually and have your own rules-based discretionary trading, you can for example eliminate some setups with your own trading experience, and also have your own re-entry on the same day in cases when the first trade got stopped out at -1R.  
You can also have the option to roll-over the trade to the next day when you have profit locked say at +3R and fight the following day for +5R, +9R and +12R ... those trade with +9R and +12R are big winners.  
  
You need to frequently check 'losing streaks' your consecutive losing trades -1R and the prevailing market conditions ... these losing streaks can wipe out the big winners.   
  
Read the OP's post. He had shown many +7.5R trades That's his winning edge.  
  
I focus on +5R trades. Anything more is bonus.  
  
There are many different scenarios when we are trading live market, ... therefore we are here to post charts and share our thoughts and how to get in and get out of the market.

**"I always set my SL to BE when the price is in the middle between the entry point and the TP."**  
  
In the percentage %Risk 'R' model with Position Sizing what is your TP for your trades.  
  
IF, your TP is set at +7.5R and you move when price is middle between Entry Price and Take Profit, then your rule is to move SL to BE when price closed above 50% of 7.5R i.e. +3.25R level.   
This can be automated using the expert advisor by the OP in post #324.

> Hi People Quick question after watching that massive move last night just after NY open is it possible to set limit and stop buy sell orders either side of price to catch the move either way,and if not can you explain why ty Cl76
> 
> Ignored

Two reasons you can’t.  
  
1\. Slippage - The loss on the losing trade will be far more than the size of your stop. I know someone that had a three point stop in place once and got stopped out at minus 60 so a potential 20R loss on a single trade.  
  
2\. Whipsaw - After big news releases it’s not uncommon for price to move violently in one direction before moving in the other so there’s potential to be stopped out in both directions.  
  
Best to avoid the big red flag news events, it’s gambling.

That depends on how the trader sees the 1-2-3 price action. Different traders have different level of experience hence different set of rules. You need to have and follow some basic rules how to determine the 1-2-3 on your chart and you need to apply rules with consistency and get the result.  
  
AUDUSD volatility has changed over the last 20 years. The good years of strong AUD is over and you will not see AUD hit parity again in the next 20 years.

Rob mentioned a few key things in his posts. The impulse move (wave) being one and then the follow through of the price action move.  
The other key thing is the market session to look for trades. He has his way to pick some of his trades - rejection candle like his last post example.  
[https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/...2#post14859472](https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/post/14859472#post14859472)  
  
  
I look at the H4 candles price action, the 4-hour trade window and look for trades with small stop loss.  
  
AU May24 example below:  
\- look for setups when the H4 candle closed,   
\- look at most recent key SnR levels Daily, H4, H1,  
\- look at the price Round Numbers   
\- I do look at the commonly used moving averages 10EMA, 50EMA, 200EMA , look at the confluence of Price Action, SnR with these EMAs ...its the herd mentality.  
  
AU May24 M15 two possible trades following the H4 candles,  
you want to pick trade setup entries with small SL and RR above 1:2.

\- re-entry on H1 completion , I check my charts once every 4 hour   
  
\- rejection of 4Hr SnR (green lines)

\- it is the Fear and Greed factor when managing trades and watching your charts  
  
\- you can consider to use the EA THV Cavemanager the OP' post in [#324](https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/post/14726213#post14726213) and manage your trades according to your exit strategy.

i assume that you bought at the arrowed candle pointing upward in your chart because you had drawn a support line but later broken, and it failed if your SL is below it.  
now refer to here [https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/...2#post14667882](https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/post/14667882#post14667882)  
it mentioned "A support zone is established using the high and close of the support candle."  
it became a support candle because it was broken and a candle closed above it and later pullback to the same level.  
you only buy when a candle tested that level and closed above it, which became the rejection candle.  
i do not see that in your chart. so that is not a rejection candle.  
the example below is showing a late retest.

intraday trading the high impact news/data like the NFP  
  
when you trade M30 take the SnR from the H4 ...  
  
trading on Friday Jun07 when there is NFP, better look at the higher timeframe for possible direction and the NFP Forecast.  
If the Forecast is better than the previous month's data, I trade the pro-dollar bias.   
When the Actual is better than the Forecast, then the analysts were wrong and you have a runaway train or a falling knife trade.  
  
The H4 'rejection' is after your little blue arrow., and hours before NFP data release.  
H4 SnR is 155.22ish  
The H4 demand zone / 'support' 155.36 was tested at LTF before the NFP release.

hi Rob  
  
Most will fail because they cannot trade like you. Its the 3Ms of trading.  
  
They have not develop their own winning systems with your basic Price Action + SnR trading. ... the Method.  
PA+SnR trading is one of the 3-M's ... less than 5% of a winning system.   
  
The 35% is the 2nd M ... Money Management which include the Risk Management aspects,  
  
The 3rd M is the Mind 60%, ... aka the trader's psychology which the mental strategies of the trader  
  
Simply put, most do not have the experience which they need to build their confidence. Experience take time, ... years of active trading the markets. You know this as you and I have been trading for many years in FF. I took the big leap in 2018 and removed the last two indicators - Stochastics and TDI, from my charts. This was exactly what [@eelfranz](https://www.forexfactory.com/eelfranz) did when he and I were trading the 5-Method way back in the 90's.   
  
>>>>> EXPERIENCE >>>> CONFIDENCE >>> DISCIPLINE > CONSISTENCY ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f4b0.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f4b0.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f4b0.png?v=15.1)  
  
My last nine(9) months Sep 2023 to May 2024 <[here](https://www.forexfactory.com/thread/post/14893915#post14893915) >  
and I only trade once every 4 hours following the Weekly and Daily charts.  
Once every 4 hours I can place my trades on any LTF chart, M30, M15, M5, based on you PA+SnR method, I prefer M5 as I automated may of my trading processes.  
  
  
Point here is for everyone to work harder at it. Be yourself, you cannot be like some one else.  
Develop trading systems that fits you.

your qualification to trade is during european session using d1 and h4.  
the example shows the d1 resistant and h4 pattern, but far away back in may.  
and in those time frames, there was no pattern found in the current market price.  
the current market price tells your the price action at the moment and is used to precise trade entry.  
you still have to make use of lower time frames to find the pattern.  
even the h1 did not present one during european session.  
however the pattern was found in m15.  
when price was around the d1 h4 h1 during european session, one should be watching out for the m15 pattern.  
however you still have the choice of not using the lower time frames.  
in that case the entry will be when the h4 candle closed below the h4 pattern, which would not be a good entry point.

Good morning, I would like to describe 2 trades that I placed on the USDJPY this morning at London open at 8.00am (a LONG which failed), and then another at 08.30am ( a SHORT which was a success). My BIAS changed from LONG to a SHORT in a single candle, and I wondered if (a) participants on this forum had these moments with 30m (b) please feel free to critique the analysis. (c) please feel free to add anything else.  
  
I would like to show my analysis, and hoping that it would inspire a conversation, and what goes on in a traders mind  
  
_**WHY LONG?**_  
I note an area of SR. candles 1,2,3,4,5,6,7 are showing Resistance.  
Several candles show support: candles 8 and two more candles to the right  
Back to Resitance with candkes 9, 10,11, 12  
candle 13 breaks higher, and it's tail is showing support  
I am aware that there is a BRN of 159.00 above (also giving Resistance), but I want to use the system as Vanilla as decribed  
  
7.30am-8.00am - as we approach London open, after candle 14 (0800) is painted and completed. It looks like a LONG, so I enter immediately at London open, with a small stop (3-4 pips), but it stopped out shortly. that's ok, that's part of the system.

_**WHY SHORT?**_  
  
8.00-8.30am. After candle 15 (at 0830) is completed, I see the upper tails, and my bias changes and take the decision that the the trade is a SHORT, and see the 3 mini tails above (from last 3 candles). Despite the longer tail below suggesting that it may continue to go long, my overbearing thought was that the last 3x30minute candles could not break through the Resistance. This coupled with Island's words that this is the market makers manipulating the market. I comfortably took the short, with a small stop, and it hit a target  
  
  
  
TARGET: my target was initially 7.5:1 as Island says, but I reduced it slightly to a previous swing Low.  
  
question: (1) Were any of these two trades valid? (2) how many other traders change their bias in a single candle? (3) any other points of view? (4) was this a fluke?  
  
Fax.  
  
update 2:Looking back at these 2 trades, it was so clear why the short was a better trade. My trading bias had kicked in. Those small tails at the top when I was looking for a LONG became almost invisible, but they were the small footprints that suggested a SHORT. The footsteps were there......

Good morning everyone,  
  
As I posted earlier, I've been backtesting the no indicator system manually using an emulator. At this point, I've gone through 18 months (2022/01-2023/06). I've been testing **only one FX pair (GBP/USD)** , my SL was often more than 10 pips, **I didn't use breakeven**(but I'm planning go through all my trades to see whether going to BE would have been more profitable), and **TP is always 7,5R**. Here are some numbers from my calculations:  
  
**The amount of trades:** 200  
**The overall gain:** 139,5 R  
**Overall gain money-wise:** from 300 EUR to 951 EUR (+217%)  
**The worst month:** -6R (2023-01)  
**The best month:** +33R (2022-02)  
**The average monthly return:** 7,75 R  
**The longest losing streak:** 9 losses in a row.  
  
For me, this is a great motivation. I'm waiting to see how it goes when trading in real-time, but I hope that I will make even more reasonable decisions and my chances won't decrease much. And to make this post more appealing, here are a few recent winning trades. Have a nice weekend!

Hey again everyone!  
Finally, I completed a manual backtesting challenge of 2 years (2022-2023) using simulator software. I've been testing Rob's system to see if I can trade it and how profitable it can be for me. Here are the final results:  
  
**Starting amount:** 300 USD  
**Final amount:** 1348 USD  
**Increase:** 349% over 2 years (14,5% per month on avg.)  
**Profitable trades:** 63  
**Unprofitable trades:** 194  
**A few facts:** I only tested the GBP/USD pair, my TP was always 7,5R, I used wider stop losses, I didn't use break even, I always close yesterday's deals before London open, there were 3 unprofitable months and 3 with profits up to 1%. Most profitable month: +33R, worst month: -6R.  
  
Normally, I backtest one month per hour, meaning that my decisions in real-time trading could be more calculated and careful. I noticed that finding the strongest SnR zones and placing SL accordingly is key for me.**Also, this backesting helped me a lot in setting my expectations right. Even though I can have 9-10 losses in a row, it doesn't mean the strategy doesn't work.**  
  
My further plan: I am going to make some calculations on these two years to see if breakeven would have brought more profits, I will also check maybe a lower (or higher) TP would be more profitable for my style of trading.  
  
Also, as I mentioned before, I have now started trading on a demo account in real time with the goal of doubling my capital. Once I reach this goal, I think I will be ready to start trading with some of my actual money.  
  
Good luck everybody! Don't stress and stay well!

hi @bigjjnem  
  
My trading hours are Sydney-Tokyo open and Frankfurt-London open   
  
When trading the Daily chart, I only need to take one trade entry per day and with set-and-forget entry, stop loss and take profit,   
and I do not need to monitor my trades.   
When we set the SL to -1R and TP to +7.5R, we will have many losses and the win rate is not great.  
But you will be profitable over the long term.   
The Money Management based strategy here is to grow an account starting at USD10,000 and grow that to USD50,000 over say 1,000 trades.  
For every USD10,000 growth in an account you add another currency pair.

Hi all,  
  
I've recently stumbled upon this thread as I'm trying to get back into Forex after a long time. I like the cleanliness of this system as it suits my personality. I want to thank Island and everyone who has contributed to the thread. It has opened up my eyes. The charts I like to work with are weekly, monthly, three month and six months charts as I find them easier to read and the S/R are not as cluttered. The problem with those charts is that you have to be patient, deal with drawdowns while watching your unrealized profits, sometime 100's of pips, go down the drain waiting for your TP to hit.  
  
I have been dabbling with this method using really small position sizes to test it out. I think I finally have the trading times nailed down so my first few trades petered out because I was trading the wrong sessions; thus, more losses than wins. I want to present GBPAUD. According to the higher time frames the bias is up so I am looking to buy. Mind you I didn't take this trade because of my time zone. I know we are supposed to draw a rectangle to indicate our desired trading zone; however, for this example, where do you draw it? Also looking at the line chart, it bounces off of a trough instead of a peak. Where is the 1,2,3?  
  
Again, I'm here to learn because I want to be a successful trader and my questions are made because I'm curious and not to critique. Thank you!

Hello traders. First friday in the month is NFP day, so no trading for me. Want to take time to analyze some trades and backtest a bit.  
I thought it´s not a bad idea to show a few examples of the importance of higher timeframes and trades which are better not to trade. Here is an example of a trade I personally wouldn´t take. GBP/USD breakdown:  
  
1.The first chart shows GU M15: It seems like we got a bullish breakout of the range + Pullback to the previous swing high + rejection candle. Seems tradable no? Let´s take a look at the higher timeframes.  
  
2\. H1 chart seems very bullish too (strong bullisch breakout candle out of the range)  
  
3\. H4 chart shows perfectly why it´s not the best idea to buy in this area (strong resistance zone just above/at the potential entry point). Do you really want to trade into this zone?  
  
4\. Daily chart speaks for itself. Previous swing low as resistance level.

Hi Crows, thanks. It´s just my second week trading this strategy, so I´m surely not a pro, even if the results are impressive.   
My plan ist pretty simple. Most recent H4 S&R as key levels to watch for (on line chart). Sometimes I adjust them on H1 timeframe. As soon as one of the key levels is reached, I switch to M15 or M30 timeframe and wait for a reversal pattern, f.e. double top/bottom or market structure shift with momentum + pullback. I don´t trade just a single rejection candle of the H4 key level. Tomorrow I´m going to show a few examples. But like I said, it´s just my second week trading the strategy on demo. If it goes well, I want to try a prop firm challenge trading this strategy.

Hi Traders,  
Just a quick note.  
When you are looking for trades, you must always be aware of the daily range. If the market has moved a big % of the daily range it is unlikely that you will get a trade in the same direction that will reach a 7.5R target. You are better off getting a reversal setup at the market open and trading back into the daily move.  
  
  
Hope this makes sense, it will save you some $ by following this simple rule. 

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

In today's session, I analyzed the NZD/USD currency pair. The price reached a key support area, which had proven reliable in the past. I noticed liquidity accumulation in this zone, indicated by brief price spikes and quick reversals. This suggested that larger market orders were being absorbed, hinting at a potential reversal.  
  
This observation was my signal to enter a long trade. The support level provided a solid base with a favorable risk-reward setup, allowing me to place a stop-loss just below it. The reduced selling pressure further confirmed the likelihood of an upward correction, presenting a promising trading opportunity.  
  
I'm new to this thread and like to contribute to this thread. I’m excited to share my knowledge and experiences, while also learning from all of you and gaining new insights. Engaging with you all is a great opportunity to grow together and deepen our understanding. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
I took my profits on the first resistance level, as I saw rejection building up on that level.

I was asked why I was breaking the rules of the system and what are the minute charts doing here?  
Let me explain. Firstly, I am overwhelmed with delight about getting to know Rob's system.  
I also like trading indices, but in liquid times the best timeframes are 1 and 3 minutes. Everything is too fast.  
By the way, I also trade in illiquid times, the speeds are low there, and the 15-minute chart is just right, but then I will get a remark that I am not trading according to the system, since now the time is not right  
somehow.  
I just made a trade on FTSE according to all the rules, except for the trading time, I am attaching the chart, but I will try not to do this again![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f92d.png?v=15.1)  
I also want to add, a huge thank you to the Rob, and wish him good luck.  
Buy 8090, st 8085, TP 8120

Hi M,  
I am going okay with health. Thanks.  
In regards to the trade, I looked at previous days bearish price action and wanted to get in short and In regards to time of trades, I entered trade as soon as I saw market activity start.  
I have eased back on trade size and extended SL size due to volatility. The SL was 10 pips and I used pivots to exit with a satisfactory RR.  
If I see support / resistance inside the 7.5TP I will use it.  
In regards to multiple lots, I have split my 1R risk into (3.3R x 3) This is not an abnormal thing to do. You will find many traders do this. It is mainly because I want to take things slower and I am not concerned about large profits anymore.  
I am just placing trades if I am at the computer and something jumps out at me. The first two trades we planned and the third I placed because it was set to go down and I wanted to take advantage of the market volatility. You have to remember I have been trading for over 35 years and can sometimes see things that others don't.  
I hope this answers your question.  
  
Just to add. I would highly recommend everyone watch the above video the ITB has posted. It is an excellent video that should be watched multiple times.  
Kind Regards  
Rob

Good day to all participants! I found this topic completely by accident two or three days ago... I read a lot, tried to understand how the system works without indicators. Numerous "gurus" only filled my brain with incomprehensible, unnecessary, completely useless, sometimes even harmful for trading information. And finally I came across this topic, like a breath of fresh air! One day was spent on quickly reading the basics - 10-15 pages, tried to make a markup. It seems to have worked... Today I looked through the entire topic from beginning to end, trying to consolidate the knowledge gained and at the same time trying to trade (there is nothing better than practice). It worked again... I make markups on cryptocurrencies, as it turned out, the fundamental principles work quite well here too. I will continue to study and practice this fairly simple system. Hi Traders,  
From now until Christmas break I am going to attempt to post my daily trade. I say trade but it might be trades or no trades depending on market conditions.  
I might not be able to post tomorrow as off to Chiropractor and visiting Grandson.  
From PM's and emails, I know some of you have had great success with my system and others have struggled.  
If you use what I have shown here in this thread and combine it with the very informative and successful thread started by Inthebox you will be on track to becoming successful, **IF** you can absorb the information and adapt. If you go over Inthebox thread images you will notice there is repetition in the charts posted. That is because the system set ups consistently replicate day after day. It is how you respond and react to the information. You need to shift your attention away from the noise and focus on yourself.  
  
So where does success come from?  
1\. It is not the system  
2\. It is not an indicator  
3\. It is the **individual**  
  
Recently I have had some great trades and also some I have been stopped out to the pip only for the market to then go in my favor. Did I beat myself up, blame algos or brokers over getting stopped out? No, I got back in the trade because I believed in my system. The trade worked out and I made some coin. This is what you need to do. There are no secrets in trading that other traders keep from you that is causing you to fail, it is you causing you fail. As soon as you admit this to yourself the sooner you can move forward. I am no genius, I am just a person like you. I don't have any special abilities that makes me better trader than you.  
What makes a successful trader is the ability to adapt to market conditions. This can be difficult for the novice due to insufficient screen time but it is possible to fast track this.  
  
My belief's  
1\. My system works  
2\. I only need one successful trade a week to increase my funds.  
3\. I am not placing trades that do not fit the entry / exit rules.  
4\. I am allowed to make mistakes.  
  
Making mistakes.  
We all make them including me, it is the trait of the human race. It is okay to make mistakes but just don't keep making them. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f644.png?v=15.1)  
  
There are many great traders here on FF that you may relate to more than me or my system. Go there if you feel that it suits you better, but make sure you stick with their system rules and work on you.  
I make no promises on your success, ultimately you are in control of you, not me.  
I will supply you my charts and notes, it is up to you to ask questions and hopefully we can get you on the right track.  
  
Another tip I will give you. It is important to take time away from the charts, the longer you sit there the more you are likely to make mistakes so, go find somewhere quiet in your house / garden and sit and switch off for 30 minutes each day. You will find questions you have will be answered when you are away from charts not when you are staring on them.  
  
Remember, every moment in time is unique, you have no control of market direction, your results, or anything else. You can plan for outcomes but don't expect them to be as you have calculated. I planned to grow old with the love of my life, I did not plan for illness and an early grave.  
You never know the cards you will get dealt, you just have to play the best game you can with them. That is what I do and will do until I cannot anymore.  
Stay positive and live in the moment.  
Talk soon ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60e.png?v=15.1)

Note: I do not give up on a short trade entry if the rejection candle high is breached. I will still monitor for another rejection candle.

You can plot your main SR lines from 4 hrs, these tend to be areas that your 7.5R TP **may** stretch into, if it is congested you may want to consider taking partials along the way. Daily tends to form a bias for you to look for trades so you stack the probabilities in your favour, in the case of yesterday since it was Monday, I looked at last Friday instead, session hi-lows and daily high-lows tend to have some significance.  
  
I found that looking at daily across a week tends to give some context, for some pairs but not all, I tend to see the majority of a move in the week made during Mon, Tuesday, Wednesday and pullbacks on Thursday and Friday. It doesn't always happen but enough times for me to pick up. Different pairs have different characteristics. You have to do your "homework" and learn the traits of the pairs you want to be trading.  
  
I suggest picking the session you want to be trading first and then the pairs when you are initially starting don't have too many pairs to work with, 1-3 should be sufficient if you don't see any set-ups as taught here for that day then just don't trade, **do not force it**

Took 3 trades during the London session today, did some intra-day post-mortem which you can use as a reference for journaling if you haven't been doing so.  
  
You can refer to post #1201, for rating entries.  
  
1\. UJ Long  
B entry, zone in the middle (Asia high) is an area to take potential partials @ 3.3R. TP target of 7.5R rests nicely in yesterday's London session if it does go all the way up.  
  
Update: Exited full position @ +5R  
  
2\. Gold / XAUUSD Long (variation of okay entry  
Rejection candle came quite late into the session, B+ (variation with wick piercing zone but body closing within zone) entry, but still within the first 90 minutes of opening. TP of 7.5R rests nicely on the Asia session's high, with minimal congestion.  
  
Update: Exited full position @ +4R  
  
3\. GU Short  
Good opportunity for a short with the rejection candle wick piercing the zone **and** failing to close within. Would have been an A textbook entry based on Rob's system, but it got cut short by the inflation news spike. -1R  
Depending on how you view this trade, it could be considered a good loss because even though I got taken out, the trade still went in my favour later on.  
  
On the other hand, you could say that with a bigger SL, you might have prevented being SL-ed, but note that the risk/reward would have become unappealing to most. Given how narrow the trading range was earlier during Asian session, **I would say that such a statement could only be made with hindsight.**  
  
Hope today's trades have shown that **even A/ A+ entries will fail** , and **trading is all about stacking probabilities**. Don't beat yourself up if quality setups don't work out. Also, **don't get attached/ fall in love** with your trades/ entries. You are simply an operator, you see a shot you take it.  
  
If trades 1 and 2 hit their TP targets, I would sit out the rest of this week and only enter further trades if I see quality (A+) setups.

The setups that Graf has posted occur on the majority of days each month.

Sometimes I place trade 1 or 2 seconds before the close of the rejection candle or 1 or 2 seconds after the close of rejection.  
I glad this has been mentioned. My apologies for not discussing this, I should have as it may have confused some of you.  
  
If the current candle is going to close as a rejection candle I will on occasion just put the order on.  
Any questions let me know.  
You have to be aware that the rejection candle is a strong rebound and if you are not quick enough you can miss an entry. Not always but just be aware of it.  
Practice makes nearly perfect.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)

Your trade order needs to be in the right place at the right time.

If there any traders that want help with this system I encourage you to start posting charts and asking questions.  
There is no such thing as a dumb question.  
I have not placed any trades today. There is red news out later and I believe that the market will likely react around US / News time.  
Something you have to remember about this system and trading in general is that, you do not need to trade every day.  
My results this week are..  
Monday +7.5R  
Tuesday +7.5R and +2R  
Wednesday no trade as yet.  
I am up 17R. Does it matter if I take anymore trades this week? I never chase the market trying to make trades appear. Your job is to wait.....wait.....attack and kick back.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60e.png?v=15.1)

Hi M,  
I stick to my trade plan / system 100%, however there are times though when I am happy to exit a trade or go to breakeven.  
You have to remember I am at the computer nearly all day and have 30+ years of trading. Saying that "Anything can happen"  
I prefer to place the trade and leave it.  
We are aiming for 7.5R winners. We won't always get them and going to breakeven has its risks.  
Stick with placing the trade, set a 1R SL and 7.5R TP and go to break even when trade is 4R and see how you go.

Hi SR,  
Well done on posting your trades. You are utilizing the line chart / SnR / Candle charts as they should be used.  
In regards to how much wick on a rejection bar should be, I like to see 2 pips as a minimum and 10 pips as a maximum.  
AU trades I use a 2 or 3 pip SL and for example GJ would be a 10 pip SL. Being in mind I pay commission on my trades so no spread to deal with.  
I noticed on your EA chart that the spread is 4.2 pips where as mine is 0.7 pips. I have recently opened an account that had a spread instead of commission and I dislike it immensely. I have had more stop being hit as they widen the spread as market activity increases.  
You will be better off with a commission broker in my opinion.

Thought I would post some details on how I prepare for trading, trade selection , trade entry, SL and TP.  
  
**Preparation for the Asian Session.**  
I start my day by opening up the following Pairs.  
AU, AJ, UJ, EA, GA, EJ and GJ.  
I can view all these pairs at the same time as I use dual monitors.  
Note: It is important to view different time frames with each pair. I start with 4hr line and candle charts side by side.  
I then go to 30m charts and finally 15m charts.  
What an looking for is the most important thing which is HTF support and resistance.  
It is of the highest importance that you have SnR plotted on your charts.  
I just want to add that although I look at seven pairs I place the greatest emphasis on AU, AJ and UJ.  
The reason is because you can get all the information from these pairs of what might be the mover for the session / day.  
Why is this? It is because AU is the base currency pair for AJ, GA and EA and UJ is the base currency pair for AJ, EJ and GJ.  
It is better to do your analysis on three pairs rather than seven.  
  
**Note:**  
If AU is rallying and AJ is also going up then EA and GA will be going down, this is showing a strong AU move up is the likely direction for the session.  
If AU is rallying and AJ is falling then I would expect EA and GA to be ranging and so I would turn my attention to UJ because it is likely that the J's are moving down.  
  
**Finding the right pair:**  
When I have identified the currency that is likely to be the mover for the session I immediately look to see where support and resistance is compared to price.  
Today is was UJ Sell. The following chart should assist in the above notes.  
The first chart is my 4hr SnR chart, this is used to identify Higher time frame SnR. On this chart I have an indicator to auto-plot the SR levels.  
  
**Note:**  
**I always double check the SR levels manually, do not rely on an indicator.**

You will notice that UJ had a go at trading higher yesterday before the close.

Trade quality not quantity.

22-1-25  
Plan Asian Session Window  
A tricky day for me to choose a target currency pair. Most pairs seem or appear in the middle & unlikely to show an entry in the next 90 min.  
  
EA  
D1 - Upward Ranging between previous L & the LH  
H4 - At the bottom of the previous swing low  
m30 - At the Support zone  
  
Note: Daily is heading up, H4 & m30 are at the Bottom & in the Support zone.  
  
Projected entry: Long with a Rejection bar at Support  
  
Adjustment: After checking the H1 bar, we have a Red Rejection candle with a suitable wick. Demo entry Long 7.5R = 52.5 pips = around the 1.66628. SL set at 1.6600 which just so happens to be a whole number.  
  
Adjustment: 7 hours after entry, market has moved more than 2.5R from entry. Moved SL to BE+1  
  
Review: Market did not reach 7.5R before it turned South at the first Resistance point of contact with a Rejection candle = a warning to exit there at around 3R.  
BE+1 was hit after market traveled +33 (4.7R) into the desired direction of target.  
The entry was good. Managing the trade as an autopilot failed (set & forget). If an eye was kept for the duration of the trade it was possible to have taken 3R from the market.

There are different options hot to manage trades.  
  
Develop your trading system' Exit Strategy based on this :   
  
  
**Option One:**  
"Cut-Losses-Short, Let Profits Run".  
  
For example, when you trade plan has the potential to run 5R, then your Stop Loss is minus 1R.  
Trade management would be simple and easy, juts use 'Set-and-Forget' and you do not need to move your initial SL and let the market decide.  
  
**Option Two:**  
Manage your trade by moving your initial SL using the R-Multiple.  
To maximize profit, be prepared to give back to the market 50% of the move i.e. protect 50% of the move.

You then have your Buy / Sell Zones.
